newsitem.title: UK: U.S. court reduces damages in Meineke case, company says.
newsitem.headline: U.S. court reduces damages in Meineke case, company says.

text.p: GKN Plc said Friday that a U.S. court had reduced the amount of damages that its Meineke Discount Muffler Shops unit must pay to some 2,500 Meineke franchises in the United States.

GKN added, however, that it still intended to appeal the decision by a federal court jury in Charlotte, N.C., that the auto-muffler retailer had mishandled and misappropriated millions of dollars charged to the franchises for advertising.
The company said the court reduced the amount of the damages to $390 million from $600 million, the largest commercial damages ever awarded against a British company in the United States.
The franchisees had brought the case against GKN in December 1993.
GKN said in a statement that it had "very strong substantive and procedural grounds for appeal." The appeal process is expected to take about 18 months, it added.
News of the damages award had sent GKN shares down sharply when first announced in December and the stock suffered a setback last week on renewed concerns about legal action from Meineke franchisees.
At last week's annual meeting one franchisee said a group of franchisees excluded from GKN's legal settlement were preparing to file a lawsuit to be re-included in the class action.

The federal judge in Charlotte, where Meineke is based, in March tripled compensatory damages of $197 million awarded by the jury in December. The jury found that Meineke had committed breach of contract, negligence and fraud.
